# specifies builtins: # this list is used to generate the java code for the builtins (via 'genBuiltin.py')
# - if no parent is specified then the most recent name is assumed
# - the most recent comment gets preserved and annotated to the java code
# - all parent classes will be renamed as Abstract<Name>
# - all classes will have their first letter capitalized
# - the overall parent class 'Builtin' - is treated specially
#   specifically listed - we nevertheless use an explitic root
# - Tags are optional -- they specify extra properties that the builtins have.
#   Both internal nodes (abstract builtins) and leafs (actual
#   builtins) can have tags. a tag will force some extra code to be

in a tree structure: and/or force it to implement some extra interface.

# specifies builtins: # - if a line gets too long
in a tree structure: tags can be continued on the next lines

# specifies builtins: #   with '-'. It is assumed that a line starting with whitespace+'-' continues the
#   tag definitions of the previous builtin
#     Defines the allowable number of parameters

in a tree structure: args() will add the interface for abstract

# specifies builtins: #     Defines what the Matlab classes of outputs are
#     input arguments. The language is defined in ClassTagLanguage.txt. Examples:
#     Allows alternative definition of class propagation that more exacty follows
#     Matlab semantics. This can only be defined for builtins for which 'Class' is defined.
#     makes this builtin abstract. By default
in a tree structure: all non-terminal node in the builtin tree are abstract

# specifies builtins: # - pure/impure: pure functions have no side effects
# - matrix:      args/operands/results are of class numerical
# - versatile:   operates on multiple kinds of classes - or subgroup of functions operates on multiple kinds of classes
# - anyMatrix:   operates on any matrix class
# - numeric:     operates on numerical classes - char/logical may get coerced to double
# - proper/improper: proper functions have strict arity

in a tree structure: binary: function takes in exactly one

# specifies builtins: # - elemnwise:   operates on matrizes (or expanded scalars) elemental
in a tree structure: and the result has the same shape as the arg

# specifies builtins: # - array:       operates on a whole matrix
# - dimensionSensitive: function is of the form f(M
with annotated information: i.e. there is a second optional parameter specifying along which dimension to operate

# specifies builtins: # - dimensionCollapsing: function that collapses a dimension (optional second arg tells which)

in a tree structure: the actual matlab behavior is different

in a tree structure: constructor etc. functions need the proper/improper categories

# specifies builtins: # pure functions have no side effects and always return the same value
# constant function - there are few of these
# general function - operates on any matrix
# any matrix functions with fixed arity
in a tree structure: where all arguments are numeric operands

# elemental unary function operating on a general matrix
# matrix-wise unary function operating on a general matrix
# binary function operating on a general matrix
# elemental binary function operating on a general matrix
# matrix-wise unary function operating on a general matrix
# improper numerical matrix functions don't have a fixed arity
# arguments that either options or different possible operands.
# functions that collapse the specified dimension
# numeric function - operates on any numeric matrix
in a tree structure: chars and logicals are coerced to double

# numeric matrix functions with fixed arity
in a tree structure: where all arguments are numeric operands
